text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like.

text: Patient: They’re there… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: Yep. Doctor: But if your PSA is zero and you feel good, it’s controlled. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: I’ll take control and we can ease up on the chemo or give you a holiday for several months and then homerun. Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay.

Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. It’s hard to say that because basically a bone scan is just about inflammation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so, if you had dental work or there’s inflammation from troubles related to the Xgeva. That would light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, if it’s the cancer that’s really causing it, then that, that would cause it to light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can’t tell ya. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, unless we stick a needle into the bone and say, “Does cancer come out?” Patient: Right. Doctor: Or is this just a hole there? text: Patient: So that would be something . Doctor: So, so, yes. Uhm um they have some things that interfere with what we do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so I’m you know all holistic approaches for all these things. I can tell you back in the day I wrote books about this stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
